The Sony az1 is a very good and cheap camera but no gimbal is available. I made a 3-axis for my hexacopter from parts from a sheep china gimbal (GLB Hobby) and it works well. Its very stiff and robust. Suitable for FPV multicopter flying with an stabilized HD camera on board. I want to share it if someone else is looking for an az1 gimbal as well.

I also made a 2-axis upper arm (UpperArm_Inf13_2axis_01.STL) if some one whants to convert the sheep china (banggood) gimbal to tho az1. located here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:963340

Ready to fly weight including camera and lensprotector = 314g
Total height = 120mm

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YGhRsebfmXI

Print the three parts and use the vibration dampening from the sheep banggood gimble. The vibration part aluminum sheets needs a 8mm hole in the middle and 1mm grinding inwards in the holes to fit the yaw motor. (I made the yaw motor turned this way to fit the aluminum part).

CamHolder_Inf20_01: I used 20% infill and 0.25mm height settings. Supports on the overhang and in the big hole.

HorizontalArm_Inf13_01: I used 13% infill and 0.25mm height. It need to be rolled 180 deg from the picture. Only supports in the big vertical hole.

UpperArm_Inf13_01: I used 13% infill and 0.25mm height. Supports in the big vertical hole and a little support on the big 45 deg overhang just for safety.

UpperArm_Inf13_360_01.STL: This upper arm has the motor turned so that the cable side is on the moving part. It allows the gimbal to turn 360 deg yaw.

On all parts I used 205 Celsius deg. PLA.

Use the old screws from the gimbal. Countersunk M3x6 (8pcs.). M2x8 (9pcs.). And suitable M3s on the top yaw motor.

The controller can be screwed or glued with double sided tape (servo tape).

Glue the accelerometer card in the "cut out" space underneath the camera holder with hot glue ( the CG allows a lot of glue to make it protected). Rout the cable inside the horizontal arm (its a bit tricky but it works. I used a guidance wire to drag it true).

There are holes in the parts for the motor cables. No supports in these holes.

The camera CG is with a lens cap clipped on.

Fasten the camera with a M4x6 in the camera threads.

Tune the PIDs according to Alexmos instructions and with the simple BGC program.

The motors are from the sheep banggood gimble Link: http://www.banggood.com/FPV-2-Axis-Brushless-Gimbal-With-Controller-For-DJI-Phantom-GoPro-3-p-908068.html With one extra motor for the Yaw. link: http://www.goodluckbuy.com/ld-power-gbm2208-2208-80-gimbal-motor-for-gopro-100-200g-digital-camera-gimbal-fpv-ptz-1.html

The controller used is this one: http://www.goodluckbuy.com/alexmos-3-axis-brushless-gimbal-controller-bgc-v3-6-drv8313-driver.html

HAPPY FLYING!!

I needed to layout full strings for a project so I extended donb's wonderful DraFont library. This version will dump all ascii characters from a font by default, and provide a method for laying out strings.
New in version 1.1: String spacing settings!
For the brave, there is a git repo at github.com/pipakin/OpenSCAD-Font-Importer (This is not for the faint of heart, my python skills are substandard at best)
NOTE: Complicated glyphs can take a long time to render, and I've managed to crash OpenSCAD a LOT by using long strings. For example, "FONTZ!" takes 1 minute 30 seconds to render, while "This is a test string." takes significantly longer (on the order of 13 minutes). So if you are going to use this for something, I recommend generating your string, rendering it, and then outputting an STL to use in your design with import_stl.

Prerequisites:
  • Python
  • Freetype (2.4.4)
  • Freetype-py
    • USAGE: python full_ddump -f [font file] -o [output file] -m [module name] Optional Parameters:
    --strings [name of strings file] (default none)
    --size [size of characters] (default 12)
    --height [z height of characters] (default 10)
    --startcode [hex unicode value to start at] (default 021)
    --endcode [hex unicode value to end at] (default 07E)
    --spacing [size in mm of spacing between letters] (default 0)
    --space [character to base the size of spaces after] (default 'x')
    --spacewidth [specific size of the space character in mm] (default none) Your scad file must include the produced scad. The produced scad references the font_base.scad file, so you'll need it too.
    example: include <FreeSerif.scad> To render a letter, you call the module with that letter (or ordinal)
    Example: FreeSerif("S"); or FreeSerif("0x41"); or FreeSerif(65); To use string layouts, you have to provide a string file. This file is a list of strings (separated by newlines). To use a string, it must match this file exactly. Then you can call the module with those strings.
    Example: FreeSerif("FONTZ!");

comments.text: I've been trying to get this to work, but can't seem to find the freetype dll anywhere.  Any advice?

Works very well! This is a great idea and a great project.
With some fonts (like ubuntu-bold), there was a problem with holes that sometimes are not removed. I had to manually add "difference()" between chunks... I will try to give you precise examples so you can update the code eventually.
By the way, it will be easy to render individual letters into hires stl files, which can be added to designs later, so there is no long wait for rendering.
Thanks for sharing this work,

author: beppemac

title: Where Shall We Travel To Today?

description.text:
“Where Shall We Travel to Today?”
The overall concept for this design was based on the many places I would like to travel to. Besides the several destinations, the artistic approach was creating model geometry using SolidWorks, and developing the idea as I went along. Some of the sketches used, had to be constrained, so that slight tweaks to the model geometry did not create “undesired” effects. I searched for images of buildings, and or structures, and from those images, and “freehanded” all of the geometry sketches to create individual models through a singular printable piece. After some consideration, I decided to make some of the pieces individual, so that they would all fit within the main base of the display. Although, not exactly scaled replicas, the visualization, and identifying structures should speak for themselves. Instead of creating one structure for this design, I felt it would be better to explore many in one concept. I felt this would be a nice display piece, which can be printed in multiple colors, or painted. The structures include the Great Wall of China, the Washington Monument, the Eiffel Tower, the Greek Acropolis Parthenon, the Taj Mahal, and the Great Pyramids of Giza. Overall assembly measures 8.39" L x 5.75" W x 6.11" H

So, where shall we travel to today?

Instructions:
Total Print Time Depends on Settings/Speed/Resolution
Approximate Print Time 12-15 Hours

1.) Base: Choose your filament material, and color. Adjust your settings to your preference. Print the base bottom up. Check part to ensure corners do not lift. You may use a raft, but be careful in removal process. Dimensions: 8.39" L x 5.75" W x 4.28" H

2.) Taj Mahal Backdrop: Choose your filament material, and color. Adjust your settings to your preference. Print with back flat on build plate. I would not recommend using rafts, as they will be difficult to remove. Check part to ensure corners do not lift. Dimensions: 7.54"L x 5.99" W x .25" H

3.) Eiffel Tower: Choose your filament material, and color. Adjust your settings to your preference. Rotate so base is flat, center on platform, and print. Dimensions: 2.625" L x 2.625" W x 5.5" H

4.) Greek Acropolis Parthenon: Choose your filament material, and color. Adjust your settings to your preference. Rotate so base is flat, center on platform, and print. Dimensions: 2" L x 1" W x 1" H

Once you have all of the parts printed, it may be necessary to clean up the parts, removing filament strands, et cetera.

If you choose to paint your display, do so prior to assembly. The Taj Mahal fits into the recess of the base, and should stand freely. Next, place the Eiffel Tower to the left upper corner behind the pyramid, and in front of the Great Wall. Place the Parthenon to the front of the base on the right side, between the footprints.

All parts were 3D printed on a Replicator 2, but fit the build volume of the Replicator 5th Generation Printer.

Your display is now ready to whisk you away to far away places!

The Brick is a speaker dock that works with the iPhone 6. There's a
hole that will accommodate the lighting cable for the 6 so you can
charge it while in use. The Brick redirects the sound from the bottom of the iPhone and acoustically amplifies it forward. Works best with an
iPhone 6 silicone case for a tighter fit.

This project was inspired by the need to create a new rack for my old small Minnesota Fats Pool Table. I could not find a replacement rack anywhere.

These are the .STL files I used to create 8- and 9- ball racks for my small pool table (D-1.5 " size balls). I created individual pieces for the sides and joints because my printer has a small build platform. I have included the FreeCAD (TM) CAD files in case makers want to modify/scale these components for a more custom design.

I printed these designs using PLA.

Feel free to make comments.

  • added 10/31/2017
    I just added to .stl files for the 9-ball and 8-ball racks as complete pieces. I did not due this initially because I designed them to be able to print on my Printrbot Simple Metal and the build platform was not big enough for full prints. I also thought people would want to modify the design for their own personalization

For 8-Ball Rack:
3 - 60dRackJoints
3 - 8BallRackSide
12 - RackPin

For 9-Ball Rack:
2 - 60dRackJoint
2 - 120dRackJoint
4 - 9BallRackSide
16 - RackPin

Glued together using loctite super glue

description.text:
An updated version of my compact geared extruder - which now has the option for helical gears.
(Helical gears are better at transferring torque smoothly and quietly - so I've upgraded my extruder to use them)

These gears are a drop in replacement - so all you need do is download and print these gears. The unchanged stl files and openscad source code are included in the zip file. Instructions are available from http://reprap.org/wiki/Mattroberts%27_Compact_Geared_Extruder

For this design, I wanted to present something unique from the standard castle build, but certainly represent mathematics. I chose to create a Nautilus shell sand mold, which represents the Fabonacci and or logarithmic spiral. Once printed, the mold can be filled with sand, and turned over onto the ground, and create a cool spiral visual. Make several at the beach and make an artistic expression!

I found a Nautilus shell image online, and traced the underside pattern, and sculpted the shell using surface modeling in SolidWorks, fleshing out the design into a solid model.

Print from bottom up. You may want to use rafts, or an adhesive on the build plate to keep part from curling.

There are a few really good designs that followed the design challenge, incorporating math with usable sand molds. If I were to win a 5th Gen MakerBot, I plan on donating a 3D printer I backed on a crowdfunfunding site to a local school, as soon as I would receive it. It is a smaller printer, but a great learning 3D printer.

Spiral out!

This simple clip design should print well even on poorly calibrated machines.  
I've added a "tooth" to the clip to concentrate the pinching force and improve it's ability to grip.  
The default settings are perfect for a MakerGear platform with heated build plate and a sheet of picture frame glass.

Set the jaw_spacing and jaw_depth parameters. I used a jaw_thickness of 5 and it works great on the default settings. Use the tooth_height parameter to set how snug the clip should be. If the clip too lose or tight, you can warm it with a heat gun and give it a little bend.

The coaxis aluminium profile from Alfer is the one used by Velleman K8200 3D printers. I got it from http://modelltechnikdirekt.de and it is useful for many other things beside construction of 3D printers. This bracket is intended to be used for mounting one of these profiles to another one with a size of 40 x 40 mm. Of course there are various situations where this bracked can be valueable.
Just a thank you note from our school for a grant.

I just don't find no 3d printed VR goggles that satisfies me, so I drew my own.

The lens holder is for 50mm lens, I might upload different sizes when I have time.

but you can always customize yourself with the provided FreeCAD file.

===

I suddently found that the front is too heavy and keeps slip down, and I happened to look for some weight to put on the back so it becames more balanced.
A broken 2.5' hdd just came into my sight... It even have it's own screw holes!

So there's another back plate which you can attach a 2.5' hdd onto.

Before you print the actual body, please consider printing the "test.stl" file, and see if your screws and nuts fits.

  • if so, you're ready to go.
  • if not, adjust inset related settings in your slicer program.

Print these with flexible material, such as TPE or NinjaFlex. How flexible these materials are is not very important, just make sure you can bend them and they won't break...

  • back_belt.stl x 4
  • phone_grip.stl x 2
  • (optinal) face_damper.stl x 4
  • top_belt.stl x 1

And print these with ordinary filaments, such as ABS or PLA:

  • lens.stl x 1
  • back_plate.stl x 1
  • base.stl x 1

You'll need some M3 screws and nuts to assemble them together:

  • M3 15mm x 1
  • M3 20mm x 4
  • M3 30mm x 4
  • M3 40mm x 2
  • M3 60mm x 4
  • M3 hexagon nuts x 15

You'll need 2 lens for that, I bought some 50mm magnifiers from local stationery store.

  • 50mm lens x 2

Assemble instructions:

  1. install the lens to the holder, with 15mm screw in the middle. remember to insert the nuts BEFORE you install the lens.
  2. install the phone grip with 30mm screws
  3. install the top belt with 40mm screws
  4. install the back belts (actually should be side belts, but I'm just too lazy to change filename) with 60mm screws
  5. install the lens holder with 20mm screws
  6. install the face dampers onto the top and bottom edge of the base
  7. take your phone, scan the qr code with google cardboard app.
  8. enjoy!

note:

  • if you happen to see the screen blurry, that's probably due to the magnify too much or too less. adjust the distance between the glass to the phone (the slider is just for this purpose...). if you just can't get it right, just install 2 pairs of lens than... (that's what I did........).

description.text: a small overhang calibrator

title: Bed leveling thumb screw with embedded nut.

description.text: A simple thumb-screw for leveling the build platform of a 3d printer. This makes it much, much easier to level the bed, as you can move the bed up and down with the touch of a finger. The thumbscrew has an embedded M3 nut placed there at mid-print, so it can be a bit tricky to make, please refer to the instrucions.

Start printing the wheel, like you normally print stuff. Do, however, make sure that all support generation is disabled in you slicer.

Pause the print when the final layer of the internal hexagon is build and insert a M3 nut into the void. The hole for the nut will be finished at 3.2mm into the build, but preview you slicers output.

I found it easiest to handle the nut by screwing it unto the tip of a M3 screw. Do verify that the nut is safely inserted into the plastic and that the upper edge of the nut is not above the top of the build (we don't want the tip of you extruder to hit it, right?).

When you are certain that the nut is positioned safely, take a few seconds to let the nut heat up to the temperature of the rest of the print. This makes it easier for the covering plastic to stick to it.

Now you just resume the print and let it finish.

Enjoy, easy bed leveling!

description.text: Adaptador para ruedas 1/10.

Yes, another spool... but I wanted a spool that was: -open on one side (to easy changing of the filament, like this clever one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8317)
-parallel to the x-axis (more direct move for the filament)
-hanging from the top (like the http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3962 used before)
-quick and easy to mount/unmount for when carrying the reprap
-and even flat transportable if possible I'm testing it right now, and it seems ok :)

• Download, cut
  • Add a bolt, a washer, a 608 bearing, a washer and a nut
  • Tighten the nut to lock the compass but not to tight to let the spool spin without too much effort
  • Place the spool spacer at the needed distance to hold your filament (maybe glue them)
  • Put it at the top of your reprap, voilÃ  :)

comments.text: I see most people try to have their spool of material on a spindle, and to have the spool unroll. When unspooling other materials (wires for electrical wiring, yarn for knitting, for example), the end piece that is pulled is taken from the inside of the spool, and pulled straight up (there generally is a pivot point above the spool, on the axis). The spool is then motionless, and the effort required to pull is really small (compared to setting in motion the spool).

This is a simple Bowden clamp with an M6 internal thread ramp, designed to fit on the hot end of a Davinci.

Once you take out the thread guide it goes straight in with an M8 (13mm) bolt to hold the bowden tube in place. I recommend sanding the last 10mm or so of the tube to get a good grip.

Once you take off the existing feeder and associated gubbins it fits in perfectly, although It's quite tricky doing the clamp nut up when it is in place :(

To be fair, this is really to see if it works (and it does https://youtu.be/jpV_-f8klWk ) consequently I have gone to a metal bowden fitting (actually the one in the picture) but you have to cut the end off the feed pipe to get that one to fit, whereas this one goes straight on.

The second photo is with the metal bowden coupling.

Note, getting rid of the extruder off the head saves nearly 400g, hence you can print a lot faster, you can also put a fan on the front which helps solidify things when you are printing that fast (100mm/s or 6000mm/min)

it's easy to print direct drive, just go slow with 100% fill

With Bowden you will need lots of retract and probably will need to print 2 at the same time.

You may need to drill out the filament hole (2mm) depending on how good you are are at getting the davinci to print one!

title: SandPress, the sand molding device - The only limit is your imagination !

description.text:
SandPress enable you to use fully your 3D printer to prepare days at the beach, with your children !

SandPress is indeed a press device that will transform easily SAND into 3D SAND SHAPES :

Want to build a castle on the beach ?

Use SandPress to mold some bricks with a RECANGULAR MOLD!

Want to build a big bridge on the beach ?

Use SandPress to mold the arches with a CIRCLE ARC MOLD !

Want to build a Greek temple ?

Use SandPress to mold the pylon with a POLYGONAL MOLD !

The only limit is your imagination ! And in 4 steps :

Step 1 : You have to print with your 3D PRINTER the shapes (side view) you want to mold on the beach.
Step 2 : Rotate the BLADE & Adapt your MOLD on the SandPress.
Step 3 : Only press the sand with SandPress to transform it into 3D SAND SHAPES.
Step 4 : Cut the sand shape with the BLADE to finish it properly !!

The best is when you get bored of your sand buidlings (castle, bridge...), you can assemble the bricks into an anther shapes =) USEFUL no ?

Sand is used in foundry to make mold. Sand is normally difficult to handle to make shapes. But, once the Sand is compress, it holds well !

SANDPRESS : Stop boring on the beach, Start Playing =)

I made this 3D thanks to SOLIDWORKS 2014.

Files are in .STL (ap203) and .STEP and .SLDPRT (SW, in the zip file).

The 3D can be print on the MakerBot 5th generation or Replicator 2 as dimensions are lower than 250160150mm and precision is 0.01 mm.

PRINT all the files : SANDPRESS + BLADE + MOLD
SANDPRESS is two piece that need to be print together.

comments.text: Quite a creative interpretation of a sand castle, something that didn't even cross my mind. Unfortunately it doesn't seem like the most original idea because I used to use these with Play-Doe. Additionally, I am not sure if this would work with sand. description.text:
The drive sled for a DVD drive (this one from an old Dell computer). Created using OpenSCAD and divided into components to help make the thing somewhat parametric and useful to others.

The aim of this design was to have an object that would seamlessly fit onto the platform and utilize the stepper-motor and rods that are left after disassembling the drive.

I printed in PLA with support material for the right-side stabilizer; however I am not sure that this is absolutely necessary.

Please note the pictures in the gallery, which show the pieces of the dismantled DVD drive that have been kept: the platform, the two metal rods, stepper motor and its support (or whatever the appropriate term is for the white piece that allows the motor to move the sled).

title: Amiibo Wall Hangers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Once I got up to 34 Amiibo I realized that I was running out of shelf space pretty quickly. I decided that I would make a simple wall-mount design so I could reclaim my bookshelf space for my comics!

Edit: I'm now up to 85 Amiibo! ans still printing these wall mounts!

Crack off the supports inside the cup that holds the Amiibo and the supports at the back where the 3M Damage Free Hanging Strips go.

These were Designed to work with Small 3M Damage Free hanging strips (pictured above)
I rip two of them off then fold them over, leaving the fold connected and adhere that so it faces upward on the wall mount. Then just stick it on the wall wherever you choose.

I've even tried this with the heaviest Amiibo that I have (Mario Party Bowser) and it held up no problem.

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=klmxXRzAuSU
https://learn.adafruit.com/talking-d20-20-sided-gaming-die/overview

The 20-sided die — or “d20” as it’s known to tabletop gamers — is an icon of geek culture. In this project we’ll 3D-print a jumbo d20 and outfit it with electronics…because that’s how we roll at Adafruit.

The talking d20 is fun and good for a laugh…though with electronics inside it won’t be 100% perfectly random or balanced…so it’s not suitable for all gaming situations and doesn’t replace your trusty dice bag. Think of it as a geek version of those “executive decision maker” toys.

The code and sounds are completely customizable. For example, you could load each of the 20 faces with the names of local lunch spots and use it to pick the day’s destination.

description.text: A second go at modeling a 180mm quadcopter frame. This one includes a flight controller vibration isolation platform and upper deck. Modeled for a standard 30mm edgewise flight controller and 12mm crosswise motor mounts.

I printed this with Hatchbox ABS with 75% infill.

I used a Flip32+ flight controller, a ReadyToFlyQuads 4-in-1 ESC, DYS 1306 3100KV motors, Gemfan 4045 props, an OrangeRC 3Ch (+ 12 S.Bus) receiver and a Spektrum Ultra Micro FPV camera.

For the upper deck I used four 30mm nylon standoffs. For the FMU platform I used 6mm rubber spacers. (6mm diameter hole in the platform and upper deck that is) For the ESC and FMU I used nylon M3 screws and nuts, with some M3 o-rings for spacers. For everything else I made extensive use of velcro tape and zip ties to get everything on it.

It can handle 3s 1000mah batteries without much issue but for indoors 2s batteries make for easier flying.

Made for my new Yi.

Used PLA. Lens cover is cut form polycarbonate 1mm.
Works well.

DXF is to cut lens cover.

If you like it just press Like :)

comments.text:

I will probably propose a slight modification to support other lens.
But it's a great idea !!

title: Hobby King Micro GPS NEO-6M Adapter Plate

description.text:
Recently purchased the Micro HKPilot Mega Master Set and found the OpenPilot Flight Controller Adapter Plates to be a nice way of mounting the controller. Unfortunately, the NEO-6M GPS that came with the set did not come with any mounting holes, so I had no way of securing the unit, mounted away from other components.

After further searching, I found the recently released ImmersionRC XuGong V2 Pro Secondary GPS Mount. Using 123D Design, I merged the STL base from IdefixRC with the cover plate from Hovership and a simple square plate to fill in gaps. After exporting out the new STL, I ran it through Microsoft's NetFabb Cloud Utility to clean up the final model for printing.

Also included in the Thing files is a copy of IdefixRC's GPS top for convenience.

author: Knoff

description.text: Update: If you mount your spools horizontally on top, I'd recommend using this filament guide instead of using spool guards: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9604 These are OpenSCAD Parametric MakerBot Filament Spool Housings. I always found Pax's excellent Spool Housings to be very difficult to print and kept thinking if only it were a little thicker so they don't delaminate or a slightly different shape, it could be even better, unfortunately I don't have Solidworks... so after having a few disasters with my stackable spool http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9198 causing filament to fall off the side and failing yet again to print enough spool housings to surround it, I wrote my own in OpenSCAD. Now that it's in OpenSCAD I can experiment with different sizes and dimensions. I can also do cool things like putting an embossed logo on the outside to add some style. :) Some changes and options I added: Caps - you don't really need to completely enclose the spool, you just need to enclose enough to prevent filament from falling off the sides, you can use caps as spacers to save time and plastic. Added a lip to the bottom to try and prevent filament from bending the housing and slipping under the spool. You can change the thickness and the degrees that each slice of housing encloses to make it much easier to print cleanly. Option to print a slice with a hole in it to tuck filament into when you change spools so it doesn't unravel. You can change the tolerance to make it fit tighter or looser on the spool. Option to print a slice with a nifty embossed MakerBot M in a circle logo (or a plain solid one). Use it as an example to make your own customized spool.

I'm still printing slices so I haven't fully tested it, so until then this is still a work in progress.  I'm thinking to fully enclose a spool, you can print 3 caps at 60 degrees each and 4 guards at 30 degrees each. (I'd suggest 3 guards with a MakerBot logo and 1 guard with a hole)  Each slice takes about an hour to print.  I'd suggest 0 extra shells and about 0.1 fill seems to be sufficient to get a good print.

description.text: Ok this is my 1st so don't hate... this should sit on the smooth rods with one thereded rod between to hold your spool. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/kHdngaQ2ibu

I got nice and cheap 7" LCD on AliExpress for some $19. Its controller supports 3 AV inputs, one VGA and one HDMI. It's universal and ideal for Raspberry Pi or install jobs.

I designed and 3D printed a case and a stand. The ports are supposed to be easily accessible, so that's why they are on top and quite visible. I had to print the case in parts to prevent warping. See instructions for detailed how-to.

The entire thing is quite big with 17 x 13 cm footprint and it was kind of problematic to print it on my Prusa i3 due to thermal warping. I had to use PLA, because with ABS it warped every time.

This thing should in theory print in just two parts and I originally designed it that way. But I was unable to actually print it. After several tries I redesigned the case to be modular. See the colored x-ray view:

  • bottom (red) is the baseplate. It's big, but completely flat.
  • middle (yellow) are four support columns. They look similar, but are not exchangeable. Use the hex holes and common sense as a guide. These columns should be superglued to baseplate. In theory, you should be able to print the piece as one, but I was unable to.
  • side_* (blue) are sides, which you will put in grooves in the support columns. You can permanently glue them with superglue or hot glue as well, if you wish.
    • Two of them (side_short and side_long) are plain solid.
    • side_buttons has five holes with hexagonal cutouts for nuts of common bushbutton switches you can use for menu buttons (power, menu, up, down, source). They aren't connected in the pictures, as I'm missing the PCB connector as of now. The hexagonal motif is repeated in the back vent holes.
    • side_connector has holes for power, HDMI, VGA and AV connector. It fits the common PCB00099 controller I'm using. The v2 versions contains mounts to screw the PCB.
  • top (green) is the LCD frame. The LCD itself is contained within the frame, in the internal cutout. The cutout is asymmetric for the LCD I'm using and you would probably have to modify it a bit.
  • legs (not pictured on overview) can be inserted to vent holes in back (bottom) part to hold the screen in two possible angles.

Entire case is held together with four M3x20 screws and captive nuts. Try to find black ones, not to stand out from the black face.

Tips:

  • Before you superglue the middle parts, triple check that you are gluing the right part to right place. I didn't and had to print most of the parts again.
  • Also check if they aren't upside down, otherwise you would not be able to put the M3 nuts in place.
  • Cover the aluminium back of LCD with some non-conductive cover to prevent shorts (I used blue electrician's tape, as seen on one of pictures. You can use black one to hide the edges from view, but I didn't had one handy.

AliExpress links:

  • LCD with controller
  • Pushbutton switches
    (Working as of time of writing.)

title: TBS Ground Station Helical Antenna GreenHorn DVR Mount

description.text: The TBS Groundstation is a neat box, and this is essentially a bracket to combine it, with the 2.4GHz helical receiver antenna, the GreenHorn 5.8GHz re-transmitter and a DVR for recording the fun :)

This is the first 'Thing' of my own design so bear with me!

Recipe:

  • TBS Ground Station http://team-blacksheep.com/products/prod:tbs_gs_2g4
  • TBS GreenHorn 5.8GHz (included in GroundStation pack)
  • 2.4GHz Helical antenna http://mongrelgear.com.au/circular-wireless-antennas/circular-wireless-2-4ghz-helical-antenna-detail.html
  • Japan FPV DVR http://www.readymaderc.com/store/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=11_14&products_id=538

Steps:

  • Print the parts. You will need to print with support just for the spigot (I printed it vertically) and the DVR holder. Greenhorn can get away without support structure.
  • Glue the spigot to the back of the antenna holder
  • Fit your antenna into the antenna holder (be careful not to break the little grabbers)
  • Screw the bracket to your ground station
  • Screw the antenna holder to the bracket.

Optional:

  • Add GreenHorn and DVR holders... or mount your own gear.

This prints in HIPS best but I have also printed in ABS (pictured in green) but the screw holes needed to be drilled back out to 3mm. The main antenna mount screw has enough tolerance it should be fine printed in either.

title: Folgertech prusa i3 x belt tensioner (drop in)

description.text:
GIVE YOURSELF THE POWER OF ADJUSTABLE X BELT TENSION!

Drop in replacement for folgertech prusa i3 non stepper X end carriage. Reworked from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:393870 to use stock pulley and 3mm screw. Z anti backlash blocks shown in picture are here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:694575 .

BOM:
1x stock X pulley, bearing and screw with nut.
1x m4x35 / 40 hex head screw
1x m4 fender washer (not necessary, just helps spread pressure)
1x m4 lock washer (once again may not be necessary)
1x m4 wing nut (could use normal nut with above lock washer, or lock nut and no lock washer)

X_END_IDLER printed at .2mm layer height and 20 percent infill with 3 top and bottom layers and 2 walls.

Roller_Pulley_X was printed at .2mm layer height and 20% infill with 3 top and bottom layers and 4 walls to make the bearing holder ears solid and provide more strength.

so, we have a baby gate we use for our dog. Every time it got wet, it would be near impossible to open...until now ! Introducing, the Baby gate bearing mount 9000.
the first version(the one shown in the pictures) was too thin and not strong enough and ended up breaking. I've tweak it to hopefully make it stronger.

If you want great prices for great quality for 3d prints to order, visit my Hub: Order a 3D Print

Parts needed:
4x M4 screws
4x M4 lock(optionally lock)nuts
4x 624zz bearings
4x nameless screws to mount onto the baby gate

The gate we have had rivets holding the metal supports on, i just drilled out the rivets and use the holes to mount the bearing assemblies.
I put the parts in acetone vapour to make them stronger

Uploaded new version, the changes are:

  • added screw to tighten insert in both parts
  • modified inserts to watch the coil while winding: coil becomes more accurate!
  • put arrow on other side, so you can hold wire with the thumb instead forefinger

I´m very happy with this new version!

Just another coil jig, works the same then the others on Thingiverse.
Addet feature are the inserts, for coils with other diameter only print the inserts 1 and 2 with the diameter fits your coil and the rod. I added some different inserts. Have fun with this thing and happy vaping :-)

author: zag14

title: Z knob for Solidoodle 4 with glass build plate

description.text:
I loved the Z adjustment knob on my Solidoodle 4 since it made it so easy to accurately adjust the Z stage height.

However, when I upgraded to Solidoodle's glass build platform the Z adjustment knob interfered with the slot in the back and would not go deep enough.

This knob design is a one for one replacement with the original knob except that the screw hole is 3 mm deeper. This allows the for correct Z stage height and keeps the knob high enough to fit in the slot.

Print the knob
Drill out the center hole with a 3 mm bit (or 1/8")
I suggest you take a picture of the current installation
remove two screws holding the support bracket
unscrew knob from bracket and keep washers and spring
unscrew bolt and lock nut from knob and keep washers
then reassemble everything in reverse order with new knob

description.text:
This is a derivative from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213858. I just hollowed it out put in a thread and created a threaded plug and voila. It sits up a little higher with the plug in as can be seen in the last picture.

Ok, not complicated but I've only had my 3D Printer for a week at this point. My plans are to put one out as a micro geocache next Easter.

Printed in ABS with a .2 layer height, 10% infill. No support needed. Used a Sharpie to color in the eyes.

I've printed 3 so far and the threads fit from tight to 'very tight'. I didn't adjust because having them very tight will make it more water/weatherproof if I put it out in the elements. I've noticed that the threads screw together a little easier after screwing/unscrewing a few times.

remixed_from.title: DaVinci 1.0 Tilted 50mm Fan Clip-On Curved Front Duct with Support

title: Davinci Fan duct modified to clear table screws..

description.text:
This is a remix of boogeymans fan duct. I modified it because when prints were near the front of the table the duct would hit the screws on the bed and mess up the print or knock the duct off.

I made it thinner which caused the air to back up so then i added width to it as well. Clears everything on my printer and runs well.

I also removed the clips because I just rather use velcro which works better for me.

Designed around a 50mm fan.
Printed at .4 no supports with PLA, printed and works well. I had a bit of a burr when the air exits which i just cut off with an exacto for cleaner air flow.

title: Stack-able Pyramid of Giza With Interior

description.text:
A stack-able version of The Great Pyramid of Giza with its internal chambers. You can separate the pyramid into 3 sections to see the location of different chambers and pathways within the great pyramid, and when you are done just stack the pyramid up and it is one solid model.

SeeTheWorld

When most people hear about the Great Pyramid of Giza, they think of just a simple pyramid, not knowing what it is like inside, so I made this project. It is to help visualize where different tombs are located within the pyramid, as well as pathways leading to and from them. Each tomb is labeled, as well as the subterranean chambers located below the pyramid itself.

Yes, you read that right. When you take a bucket 'o Octopi, Octopodes, and a torus... the question everyone wants to know is, Will It Blend?
Blender.org to the rescue.
This bona-fide Identified Flying Object (IFO) has a clever little octopus clutching on for dear life. He knows the fastest way over yonder is when you hurl him through the air.
Anyone that can add a good, printable scarf and aviators to the original file will get $5 from me.

This little guy was printed on a RepRap Mendel. You may need to scale to print on your printer (scale it up if you can!). Support Material is a MUST. There's nothing on the inside, see the pics. If you want to use our skeinforge41 profile that uses E-codes, check it out here:
https://github.com/tesla893/RepRap-World-Tour
use commit:1da1093a8e80a45746dc the dot.skeinforge is your ~/.skeinforge folder and skeinforge41 is, well, skeinforge41.

author: UltiKid

title: Radio Shack TRS-80 Model 102 Battery Cover

description.text:
This was precipitated by repeated requests and discussions on the TRS-80 Model 100 mailing list:
Model 100 Discussion [email protected]

This version doesn't have the rabbet on the outer edge of the cover. Since it prints upside down, that only serves to add unnecessary support material around the periphery.

This has NOT be verified to fit, but is based on a flawed
"Tandy 102 Battery Door" by joehms22 and on exhaustive measurements by David Flippo. Someone print it out and let me know it works.

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license. with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design.

You're going to need to slice this with support enabled. I am sorry, but the locking tabs require unavoidable overhangs. BE SUPER SUPER CAREFUL TRIMMING SUPPORT MATERIAL OFF THE BATTERY COVER. It would be far too easy to snap off a tab during finishing. Ask me how I know. I printed this is PLA, but ABS might be more forgiving.

comments.text: I printed this and can verify that it fits and works properly.  It's a REALLY tight fit, I think that is a combination of the locking tab and the material I used to print it.  I printed it via ShapeWays, using their "black, strong and flexible" material.  I'm going to see if it wears in a bit over time, but am very pleased with the way it came out.

author: mozart

title: Modular X-ends || Sturdy & Easy to Print

description.text:
These are my X-ends. They consist of three different parts that can be printed separately and then assembled with 3mm bolts and nuts, don't forget washers. If say the motor holder breaks you can print only that part. Motor and idler mount should less likely break when tightening X-belt since they are printed flat against the bed. Works with LM8UU. Put the M8 nut on the underside only and add a really small drop of super glue if you think it needs it. I haven't actually printed this yet, but will soon. Sivar has had some good experience with this and has been a real help. Check his print from the "Made"-section. Updates:
6/13/2013: Added thin raft to a part that was prone to detach from bed. 6/2/2013:
Added V3 files. The smooth rod clamping is now completely different and should fix the bending that happened before. V3 parts are compatible with original ones, so if you already printed the first files but wan't to test out the new base, it will work with your existing motor and idler bracket.

title: Modified Plunger for 60ml Syringe Extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I modified the tip of the plunger so that the shape matches the actual plunger that came with the 60CC syringe.

Doing this allowed us to use the actual plunger seals from the 60CC syringe itself.

The original print as seen in the first picture, was not suitable for these seals.

We also reinforced the 3Drag_platform because the original one kept cracking during mount.

See it in action on this Kickstarter:

http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/881313008/3d-circuit-printing-kit

author: Drdray1

description.text:
A case for a Chinese Mega 328 ESR meter. This unit ships direct from Shenzhen, and features a 9 volt battery and power adapter slot.

Realize there are a LOT OF DIFFERENT Mega 328 ESR meters - this may not fit your board. I couldn't find one that fit mine when I looked at Thingiverse, so I thought I'd upload this. Make sure you look at your ESR board and see that it looks like this one.

This is one of my first designs, so it's not perfect.

If your printer is calibrated, the posts should fit the holes in the board well.

Changes I'd make, given the time:

  • The latch that holds top and bottom of case together is flimsy. Needs an update.
  • The case needs 1mm more clearance around the board.
  • The latch should not interfere with the board locator pins.

comments.text: Mine is the transistor, diode, mosfet, capacitor, and resistor mega328 component tester.

author: cgilfill

title: BI Spool Holder Remix for Thrust Bearing

description.text:
Firstly, the Boots spool holder is a fairly awesome design! I love that it is fairly low profile and has a bearing for smooth payout. I was a bit bothered by the fact that the 608 bearing is used under load in a horizontal orientation. While there's not a ton of sideload on the bearing, it is nevertheless not great for the longevity of the roller skate bearing. I also had to print a 2nd base for the holder when I first tried to use it because the small (8mm) peg that the bearing sits on just snapped off when the spool leaned a bit too far one direction.

So I remixed this with a larger platform to hold a thrust bearing (XP51105) which I bought on amazon for $2.67
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00C1X0A2M?

The bearing sits flat on the base and over the larger diameter column in the middle to keep it centered. A 4mm bolt will thread down into the hole in the center, and if you have a large washer under the head of it you can tighten the bolt to put a tiny bit of "drag" on the holder so your filament doesn't just unwind itself into a pile.

author: Whiskerpibb

description.text:
Side panels for the Minion quadcopter. They were designed to be used with the Minion PDB, so the white LED's can still be seen. If you print this with translucent filament, those LED's will light up the side pretty well. This design also has holes in the front and back so you can use a zip tie to ensure they stay on, although, if you position the posts correctly, they will stay on without the zip ties. There is also a notch on the top because I use the zip tie with shrink wrap antennae holders for my D4R-II receiver.

In the pictures, I added lettering to the side. The files do not have letting on them so you can add your own designs if you wish, or leave them flat.

Based on the instructions from the youtube video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7YWTtCsvgvg

Can be used as is for normal or scaled up panels.

Slots might be a bit snug though as they were built based on a thickness of 1mm.

UPDATE!
V2 out (yea... pretty quick huh... >.<)
V2 is adjusted so that the slots are now 2mm thick instead so it should work better with fitting in the panels.
Legs are also thicker.

description.text: Replacement bed for an old Matchbox No. 37 Skip Truck.
Will need to print with support for the overhand on the hooks. I had to do a little filing on the hooks as well to get it to fit the mounting point.

https://vimeo.com/135430249

Not only do I need to vortex many eppi tubes, I need to gently agitate them for ~20 minutes. To facilitate this second step, I built a little rotator that the vortexer assembly slides into.

I repurposed a burnt up servo from other projects to provide the rotation. This is still a work in progress.

I intend to utilize this Striker Assembly to create an open source Paintball/Nerf gun. I have very little time right now to work on the project, so I thought I would post what I have and see what people thought.

The parts are intended to be machined on Lathes and Mills. However, it would be interesting if someone could do a study on printed parts and their ability to contain pressure (exercise extreme caution with this!!! I would start at 10psi and work from there). I will be posting more designs later for a couple of paintball guns using this design. There are two springs, not pictured in this part. One that spans the gap from the red part to the green, and one one the oposite side, from the blue part to the aluminum colored one.

remixed_from.author: random11
remixed_from.title: Master Ball, with magnetic clasp (Fixed Lid)

title: Luxury Ball, with magnetic clasp (In Parts)

description.text:
This version of the luxury ball with magnetic clasp lets you assemble the lid and bottom shells with each section/color separated out into different parts. There are a lot of parts so I figured I would separate this into its own thing. If you would rather print the lid all as one piece please see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:953054

Print all the parts out. Print two of the Lux_Lid_Silver_Ring.stl you will need one for the lid and one for the bottom shell.

I printed most of the parts with 1 shell except for the Lux_Ring and the Lux_Lid_Silver_Ring, where I used 2 Shells. And only the Silver Ring part needs supports. I also used 100% infill on the silver ring part because it is a little more fragile then the other parts.

All the lid parts snap together really tightly so you wont need glue.

To assemble the Lid correctly first print out the black base and then attach the gold ring 1 to it. Make sure it is fully snapped into position. Then snap on the red ring, then finally the second gold ring, and the silver ring.

After assembling the lid and the bottom you can glue the button and the ring to the bottom with the hinge in place as you glue the ring down. Then snap the hinge into the lid.

You will also need 2 magnets (1/4" X 1/16"). Just glue them in place.

Tip: Print your bottom piece at a higher in fill percentage, around 40-50% and then all the other parts at 5-10%. That way it will be bottom heavy and not roll around as much.

title: Dolhareubang ("Stone Grandfather") - Keychain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Jeju Island, known as the Hawaii of South Korea, is a popular holiday destination.
(http://edition.cnn.com/2014/04/16/travel/jeju-island-introduction/)

Dolhareubang means "stone grandfather".
Dolhareubangs are stone statues(1.3~ 1.9 m tall) found on Jeju Island off the southern tip of South Korea.
Dolhareubang is often regarded by Jeju folks as the god of protection and fertility, also believed as the guardian of Jeju Island.
Dolhareubangs are easily seen everywhere in Jeju Island as the statue of an old man sculptured from a block of basalt.
(http://www.antiquealive.com/Blogs/Dol_hareubang_Stone_Statue_Jeju_Island.html)

Actually it is difficult to generate a real 3D model of Dolhareubang from photos.

So, I bought a replica of Dolhareubang sold as tourist souvenirs.

By using this souvenir, I created the 3D model of Dolhareubang.
And I designed another 3D model for keychains.

How to make 3D-printable models :

  1. Generate a 3D model from photos by using Autodesk 123D Catch(http://www.123dapp.com/catch),
    I create a 3d model of Dolhareubang from 18 photos.

  2. Modify a 3D model by using Autodesk Meshmixer(http://www.123dapp.com/meshmixer),
    I made another 3D model for keychains.

Cura setting values:
-. 0.2mm layer thickness, 0.8mm shell thickness
-. 25% ~30% fill density
-. 30mm/s print speed
-. 10mm/s outer shell speed, 10mm/s inner shell speed,

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. You will need to print the ice cream cone separately. It works nicely if you print them in two different colors. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9h7qAcIYNy0

My "thing" is very simple. I made a pyramid in one file for the cone and a half roof in the other. I made sure that the squares were the same size so they would match up. After printing, I super glued, the two shapes together to make them look like an ice cream cone. My inspiration was my brother-in-law being a smarty pants on facebook asking if I could print an ice cream cone with my new 3D printer.

description.text:
I'm a young professional pilote in training and I would like to share a part of my travel that I do with my training.
In this objective I would like to virtualize some famous monument and place it on this 3D printed piece.

With this project you can see a lot of most famous monument in the all world !

I would like this project as a personal adapting art, in deed you can put every monuments you want, lets see the instruction for more informations !

You have to print separately the all monuments and the earth.
After you can put anywhere your monuments, you can create new or juste use the monuments you find on internet !

It is your personal art and you can customize as you want but dont forget to share !

The earth could be printed in magnetic material and the monument too. This allow you to place where you want and as you want the monuments !

title: 608 Bearing spool holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have slightly modified the great design of the Bearing spool holder from chylld www.thingiverse.com/thing:7001.
I fits reels from www.watterott.com and www.reprapsource.com which seems to come from orbi-tech.de.
The bearing holders are designed to fit a 608 bearing and they are placed into the spool centre holes, with lips to stop them from going all the way through.

Print 2 of each part (2 bearing holders, 2 spool sides, 2 'a' feet, 2 'b' feet). a and b feet are from the original thing www.thingiverse.com/thing:7001 Assemble with 8mm wooden dowels of the following lengths: 1x 14cm - between the bearings
2x 27cm - base (long)
2x 16cm - base (short)
4x 23cm - diagonals

comments.text: You sir, are a genius. The plastic bearings in the original design are cute but worthless.
comments.author: beemo

comments.text: I just finished printing all the parts for this, except I realized this only works with the larger (2.3Kg) spools.  I'll be re-designing the bearing holders to work with the smaller 1kg spools I have a few of!
